docs.lead_paragraph: A doctor was convicted of manslaughter today, and a former clinic administrator was found guilty of negligent homicide in the death of a patient after a late-term abortion. The doctor, John Biskind, and the former administator, Carol Stuart-Schadoff, had been charged with manslaughter in the death of LouAnne Herron after an abortion at the A-Z Women's Center in Phoenix on April 17, 1998. An autopsy found that Ms. Herron's uterus had been ruptured by an instrument.

headline.main: National News Briefs; Two Are Convicted In Postabortion Death

docs.abstract: James Biskind, 75-year-old doctor, is convicted in Phoenix of manslaughter in death of patient after late-term abortion; former clinic administrator, Carol Stuart-Schadoff, 63, is found guilty of negligent homicide in death of LouAnne Herron in 1998 (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Years before the gimmickry of ''Survivor,'' ''Temptation Island,'' ''The Mole'' and the other reality shows now swamping television, there was ''The Real World.'' MTV's ''Real World'' has just started filming in New York for its 10th season, to begin in June. It is not only the most enduring reality series on television -- and the forerunner of the newer shows -- but also more connected to viewers' lives. Not set in jungle, desert or exotic locales, as are many of the newer shows, and not cast with adventurers and often volatile, sometimes bizarre personalities, ''The Real World'' deals with the lives, loves and other personal issues confronting the MTV generation.

headline.main: Getting Real Before Anyone Else; MTV's 'World' Rolls On With Voyeurs on Its Coattails

docs.abstract: MTV's Real World starts filming in New York for its 10th season; it is most enduring reality series on television--and forerunner of newer shows--and is seen more connected to viewers' lives (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: They are young, smart and bitter. They are the victims of the recent wave of layoffs in the high-technology industry, and many of them cannot believe how clumsy their former employers were in delivering the bad news. Patrick Mannion learned his fate on Dec. 20 when he returned with his wife from a two-week honeymoon in Hawaii to their home in Montclair, N.J. The pink slip telling him his job was eliminated days earlier was waiting for him in a FedEx envelope sent by Organic Inc., an Internet consultant in San Francisco.

headline.main: Management: Discarded Dreams Of Dot-Com Rejects; Growing Indignation Results From Recent Brusque Dismissals

docs.abstract: Many young people laid off by high-technology companies say they cannot believe how clumsy their former employers were in delivering the news; their indignation threatens to tarnish reputation of some companies; court filings by aggrieved workers and settlements with their former employers are increasing sharply, and number of lawsuits is expected to grow; much of problem results from seat-of-the-pants management mind-set that worked well in Internet boom of 1990's but can be disaster when applied to task of dismissing people; jobs cuts at Internet companies surged to 12,828 in January, 23 percent increase over December; since January 2000, over 50,000 jobs have been eliminated; graph; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: IN November 1997, Dr. Michael Tanner, director of the primary care clinic at Bellevue Hospital Center, asked Rick Jordan, an artist, to create a mural for his living room. Dr. Tanner expected the job to take a few weeks and cost about $2,000. Three years and $30,000 later, Dr. Tanner has walls that would have suited the Medicis. He also enjoys what is surely one of the most personal interiors in New York City. This is not a surprise, considering Mr. Tanner's lineage. He is the son of Patrick Dennis, the author of ''Auntie Mame'' and a true original. ''We had a brownstone of no distinction,'' Dr. Tanner said of his childhood home on East 91st Street. ''Dad demolished the second floor to create a living room with 20-foot-high ceilings, so he could hang these giant tapestries on the walls.''

headline.main: A Trompe l'Oeil Supported by Grand Allusions

docs.abstract: Interview with Dr Michael Tanner on interior design of his New York City apartment, including decorative painting by Rick Jordan inspired by 15th-century work; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Jane Swift, the lieutenant governor of Massachusetts, first drew national attention in 1998 for campaigning while pregnant. Then, last year, she faced fire for ethical lapses that included asking aides to baby-sit for her little daughter. Now, she takes on an even greater challenge: She is expected to take over within weeks for the current Republican governor, Paul Cellucci, who has just been picked by President Bush to be ambassador to Canada.

headline.main: 2 New Jobs for Massachusetts Official: Acting Governor and Mother of Twins

docs.abstract: Jane Swift, lieutenant governor of Massachusetts who is pregnant with twins, is expected to take over within weeks for current Republican governor Paul Cellucci, who has been picked by Pres Bush to be ambassador to Canada; she would be first woman to govern Massachusetts, and experts say she would also be first American governor to give birth while in office; Swift first drew national attention in 1998 for campaigning while pregnant; last year she faced fire for ethical lapses that included asking aides to baby-sit for her; Swift's initial mishandling of situation cost her much of sympathy she had at first from parents performing their own child-versus-career balancing acts; photo (M)
